title: Shrimp & Pineapple Fried Rice
subtitle: with Cashews & Sambal Oelek
time: Though it has become a fixture in Americanized Asian cuisines, the pineapple is actually native to Brazil. From there it spread to Europe, and it wasn’t until the 1500s that the pineapple began appearing in Indonesia and China. Because of its wonderful sweetness (historically it’s been called the “princess of fruits”), it’s often used to accent savory flavors, which is what we’re doing here. With sambal oelek (a chunky chile sauce), shrimp, scallions and cashews, this fried rice is a delightful collage of flavors (and colors, too).
desc: Though it has become a fixture in Americanized Asian cuisines, the pineapple is actually native to Brazil. From there it spread to Europe, and it wasn’t until the 1500s that the pineapple began appearing in Indonesia and China. Because of its wonderful sweetness (historically it’s been called the “princess of fruits”), it’s often used to accent savory flavors, which is what we’re doing here. With sambal oelek (a chunky chile sauce), shrimp, scallions and cashews, this fried rice is a delightful collage of flavors (and colors, too).

steps.title: Prepare the ingredients:
steps.desc: Wash and dry the fresh produce. Thinly slice the carrots into rounds. Small dice the pineapple. Peel and mince the garlic. Cut off and discard the root ends of the scallion; thinly slice the scallion, separating the white bottoms and green tops. Using a peeler, remove the green rind of the lime, avoiding the white pith; mince the rind to get 2 teaspoons of zest (or use a zester). Quarter the lime and remove the seeds. Roughly chop the cashews.

steps.title: Make the garlic-lime rice:
steps.desc: In a small pot, heat 2 teaspoons of oil on medium-high until hot. Add the garlic and cook, stirring frequently, 30 seconds to 1 minute, or until lightly toasted and fragrant. Add the rice, lime zest, 1 1/2 cups of water and a pinch of salt. Heat to boiling on high. Once boiling, cover, reduce the heat to low and simmer 11 to 13 minutes, or until the liquid has been absorbed. Remove from heat and fluff the finished rice with a fork.

steps.title: Toast the cashews:
steps.desc: While the rice cooks, heat a large, dry pan (nonstick, if you have one) on medium-high until hot. Add the cashews and toast, stirring frequently, 2 to 3 minutes, or until lightly browned and fragrant. Transfer to a bowl and set aside. Wipe out the pan.

steps.title: Cook the vegetables:
steps.desc: In the same pan used to toast the cashews, heat 2 teaspoons of oil on medium until hot. Add the carrots and cook, stirring occasionally, 2 to 3 minutes, or until softened. Add the white bottoms of the scallions and cook, stirring constantly, 30 seconds to 1 minute, or until fragrant.

steps.title: Add the shrimp & pineapple:
steps.desc: To the pan of vegetables, add the shrimp and pineapple; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring frequently, 2 to 3 minutes, or until the shrimp are cooked through and opaque.

steps.title: Finish & plate your dish:
steps.desc: To the pan of vegetables and shrimp, add the garlic-lime rice, soy sauce, toasted cashews, the juice of 2 lime wedges, 2 tablespoons of water and as much of the sambal oelek as you'd like, depending on how spicy you'd like the dish to be. Cook, stirring frequently, 2 to 3 minutes, or until thoroughly combined and heated through. Divide the shrimp and pineapple fried rice between 2 dishes. Garnish with the green tops of the scallion and remaining lime wedges. Enjoy!
